item.label: Cerebral gyrus, Uncus
item.name: Cerebral gyrus Uncus
item.description: The uncus is a bulge on the anterior aspect of the parahippocampal gyrus caused by the underlying amygdala. it can herniate through the tentorial notch in the event of increased intracranial pressure due to a supratentorial space-occupying lesion.

item.label: Cerebral sulci & fissures
item.name: Cerebral sulci_fissures
item.description: A cerebral fissure is AKA a cerebral sulcus (sing.); sulci (pl.).  Fissures are the depressions or grooves between the gyri or convolutions of the cerebral cortex.  Fissure generally refers to a sulcus that is particularly deep.  The terms are used interchangeably in some cases.

item.label: Central sulcus
item.name: Central sulcus
item.description: The central sulcus (of Rolando) is an important sulcus on the lateral aspect of the cerebral hemisphere that separates the frontal from the parietal lobes. It extends from just medial to the superior border of the hemisphere downward to the lateral or Sylvian fissure. The primary motor and somatosensory areas of cortex form the gyri (pre-central and post-central, respectively) on either side of this sulcus.

item.label: Calcarine sulcus
item.name: Calcarine sulcus
item.description: The calcarine fissure or sulcus is AKA as Area 17 of Brodmann. It is a prominent sulcus on the medial surface of the occipital lobe consisting of an upper bank (cuneus) and lower bank (lingual gyrus) where the neurons of the primary visual cortex are located.

item.label: Commissure, Anterior
item.name: Commissure, anterior
item.description: The anterior commissure is a small and compact bundle of commissural axons located just beneath and caudal to the rostrum of the corpus callosum. It connects corresponding areas in the temporal cortices as well as olfactory structures.

item.label: Fornix, Crus
item.name: Fornix, crus
item.description: The crus is that portion of the fornix between the fimbria and body of the fornix. It curves superiorly to just beneath the splenium of the corpus callosum.

item.label: Internal capsule
item.name: Internal capsule
item.description: The internal capsule is a thick fiber bundle that is the primary route of communication between the cerebral cortex and other CNS structures. It includes the thalamocortical, corticothalamic, corticospinal, corticobulbar, etc. tracts. It consists of an anterior limb, genu and posterior limb that form a "V" shape as seen in mid-level horizontal or axial sections.   The lenticular nucleus (putamen and globus pallidus) is located laterally inside the "V" and the caudate nucleus and thalamus are located medially.

item.label: Anterior limb
item.name: Anterior limb
item.description: The anterior limb of the internal capsule is located between the lenticular nucleus laterally and the head of the caudate nucleus medially. It includes thalamocortical fibers from the dorsomedial and anterior thalamic nuclei to the prefrontal and cingulate areas of cerebral cortex as well as corticopontine fibers.

item.label: Genu
item.name: Genu
item.description: The genu of the internal capsule is located where the anterior and posterior limbs meet. It includes connections between the ventral anterior (VA) and ventral lateral (VL) thalamic nuclei with the motor/premotor cerebral cortex as well as corticopontine fibers.

item.label: Corpus striatum
item.name: Corpus striatum
item.description: The corpus striatum includes the caudate nuclei, putamen and globus pallidus.  These nuclei are often referred to as the basal ganglia.   Note that the term "striatum" includes only the caudate nuclei plus the putamen.

item.label: Caudate nucleus, Head
item.name: Caudate nucleus, head
item.description: The head of the caudate nucleus is the largest portion of the caudate.  It bulges into the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle. It is located medial to the anterior limb of the internal capsule.

item.label: Lentiform nucleus
item.name: Lentiform nucleus
item.description: The lentiform nuclei are AKA the lenticular nuclei. These nuclei include the putamen and globus pallidus. Located lateral to the internal capsule and medial to the external capsule, claustrum, extreme capsule and insula, the lenticular nucleus fills the "V" formed by the lateral surface of the internal capsule.

item.label: Putamen
item.name: Putamen
item.description: The putamen is the large lateral component of the lentiform nucleus, located lateral to the globus pallidus and the internal capsule. With the caudate nucleus, it is known as the striatum. Portion of the striatum most involved in the motor function of the basal ganglia. Receives afferents from motor and somatosensory cerebral cortex, substantia nigra and centromedian nucleus of the thalamus; sents efferents to globus pallidus.

item.label: Globus pallidus
item.name: Globus pallidus
item.description: The globus pallidus is a wedge-shaped nucleus located medial to the putamen and fitting into the "V" on the lateral aspect of the internal capsule. With the putamen, it is known as the lentiform or lenticular nucleus. It is the origin of most efferents from the basal ganglia. Includes an internal and an external segment.

item.label: External segment
item.name: External segment
item.description: The lateral component of the globus pallidus is known as the external segment.  It receives afferents from the striatum and subthalamic nucleus and sends efferents to the subthalamic nucleus via the subthalamic fasciculus.

item.label: Internal medullary lamina
item.name: Int medullary lamina
item.description: The internal medullary lamina of the globus pallidus is a thin layer of nerve fibers located lateral to the internal segment of the globus pallidus and medial to the external segment of the globus pallidus.  Do not confuse with the internal medullary lamina of the thalamus.

item.label: Internal segment
item.name: Internal segment
item.description: The medial component of the globus pallidus is known as the internal segment. It receives afferents from the striatum and subthalamic nucleus and sends efferents to the thalamus via the ansa lenticularis and lenticular fasciculus.

item.label: Basal forebrain area
item.name: Basal forebrain area
item.description: The basal forebrain is the general area of the forebrain near the inferior surface of the telencephalon between the orbital gyri and the hypothalamus. It includes the substantia innominata area, septal area, anterior perforated substance, etc.

item.label: Diencephalon, Thalamus
item.name: Diencephalon Thalamus
item.description: The thalamus is a large collection of nuclei that have major connections with the cerebral cortex involving both sensory and motor functions. Some thalamic nuclei have very specific connections relative to visual, auditory and somatosensory afferents and their projection to specific areas of cerebral cortex, while other nuclei have more general inputs and connections with association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Lateral posterior nucleus
item.name: Lateral posterior nucleus
item.description: The lateral posterior nucleus of the thalamus (LP) has connections similar to those of the pulvinar, i.e. with posterior association cortex.

item.label: Medial geniculate nucleus
item.name: Medial geniculate nucleus
item.description: The medial geniculate thalamic nucleus (MGN) deals with hearing.  It receives input from the cochlea via the cochlear nuclei, lateral lemniscus and inferior colliculus. It projects to primary auditory cortex in the temporal lobe (transverse temporal or Heschl's gyri) via the sublenticular part of the internal capsule.

item.label: Pulvinar
item.name: Pulvinar
item.description: The pulvinar is the largest of the thalamic nuclei. It has connections with parietal-occipital-temporal association cerebral cortex.

item.label: Ventral posterior lateral nucleus
item.name: Ventral posterior lateral
item.description: The ventral postero-lateral thalamic nucleus (VPL) deals with somatosensory information from the body. Afferents to the nucleus arrive via the medial lemniscus and spinothalamic tracts. This nucleus sends efferents to post-central gyrus of cerebral cortex via the posterior limb of the internal capsule.

item.label: Visual pathway, Optic tract
item.name: Visual pathway Optic
item.description: The Optic tract consists of optic nerve axons that serve the contralateral visual field.  These axons originate in the ipsilateral temporal retina and contralateral nasal retina and terminate in the lateral geniculate nucleus as well as the pretectal area.

item.label: Midbrain, Cerebral crus
item.name: Midbrain Cerebral cru
item.description: The cerebral crus is AKA the crus cerebri or the basis pedunculi. This most ventral or inferior aspect of the paired cerebral peduncles contains motor axons originating primarily in the cerebral cortex. The bulk of the cerebral crus is made up of the corticospinal, corticobulbar and corticopontine tract fibers that have left the cerebral cortex, traveled through the internal capsule and will terminate in the spinal cord and brain stem.

item.label: Cerebellum, Hemisphere
item.name: Cerebellum, hemisphere
item.description: The cerebellar hemispheres are the largest portion of the cerebellum located on either side of the midline vermis. They are functionally important relative to coordination of the limbs.

item.label: Cortex
item.name: Cortex of cerebellum
item.description: The outer cortical surface of the cerebellum is folded into fine-caliber ridges called folia.  This cortex consists of three layers, an outer molecular layer, an inner granular layer and a Purkinje cell layer in the middle at the junction of the molecular and granular layers.

item.label: Medullary center
item.name: Medullary center
item.description: The medullary center of the cerebellum is the white matter in the center of the cerebellum.  It is composed of the nerve fibers traveling to and from the cerebellar cortex and deep cerebellar nuclei.

item.label: Dentate nucleus
item.name: Dentate nucleus
item.description: The dentate nucleus is the largest and most lateral of the deep cerebellar nuclei. It appears as a highly-convoluted draw-string purse with a small opening or hilus from which its efferent fibers exit on their way to the superior cerebellar peduncle. Afferents to the dentate nucleus are primarily from the neocerbellar cortex or lateral aspects of the hemispheres. Efferents terminate primarily in the ventral lateral nucleus of thalamus. Because of a similar shape, it can be confused with the inferior olivary nucleus found in the medulla.

item.label: Middle cerebellar peduncle
item.name: Middle cerebellar peduncl
item.description: The middle cerebellar peduncle consists exclusively of pontocerebellar tract fibers that take their origin from pontine nuclei in the contralateral basilar pons. Thus, it carries afferent information to cerebellum from the contralateral cerebral cortex via the corticopontine to pontine nuclei to pontocerebellar tract.

item.label: Ventricular system,Lat Vent,Trigone
item.name: Ventricular system La
item.description: The lateral ventricle is a large, C-shaped space within each cerebral hemisphere that is filled with cerebrospinal fluid. It consists of an anterior (or frontal) horn that extends into the frontal lobe, a body, a posterior (or occipital) horn that extends into the occipital lobe, an inferior (or temporal) horn that extends into the temporal lobe and the atrium or trigone where the body, posterior limb and inferior limb meet.

item.label: Choroid plexus
item.name: Choroid plexus
item.description: The choroid plexus is the convoluted and highly vascularized structure in the ventricles that is responsible for the production of cerebrospinal fluid.  It is located in the floor of the lateral ventricle as it curves from the body of the ventricle into the inferior horn; it is not present in the anterior or posterior horns of the lateral ventricle.  From the lateral ventricle, the choroid plexus extends through the interventricular foramina of Monro onto the roof of the third ventricle.  In the fourth ventricle the choroid plexus extends downward from the inferior medullary velum that forms part of the roof the ventricle.  The choroid plexus also extends from the fourth ventricle through the foramina of Luschka into the subarachnoid space.
